title: How to use psychology to manipulate people - Quora

response.answer_text: This is a brutally honest answer: To manipulate people successfully, you need to learn three things first. You need to understand people's nature very well. Then find their vulnerabilities which you have to use and take advantage of. Affection, caring nature, simplicity, wish to help others, trustfulness.....these are "weaknesses", not "virtues" to you and you have to use these to control and dominate him. Secondly, you have to develop a lot of skills with which to control your victim. Always remember, it's not brute force you're using, it's cunning manipulative skill. You have to be skillful enough to use him coldly for your own gains and still to keep him under your domination. Lastly, you have to be cold and ruthless. If the victim suffers to do what you want, it's nothing to you! What matters is only your selfish desire. Basic manipulation tools come from a real good acting skill. You have to be good at convincing people. Be an austute observer of peoples' nature and find their vulnerabilitirs. Develop a false relationship with the victim. It will help you to gain his trust and affection. After that, the process of domination and mind control begins. This is the hardest part. You have to feed him lies, entangle him in your web of lies. When necessary, feed him half-truths (gaslighting). Play on their emotions. Take every opportunity of their affection, sense of responsibility and the disease to please others. Seduce them with charm, flattery, superficial sympathy etc. Never hesitate to be humble and to apologize when you need the victim's help. But, possibly the most powerful weapon will be your playing the victim role. Falsely accuse the victims of being selfish and not helping you. The conscienous and rational people fell very easily in this trap. For the emotional victims, use it with a mixture of emotional blackmail. What if the victim tries to break the bondage? How can you be able to supress the rebellion? Here is the usage of another side of the manipulator, more dark and frightful to the victim. You have to break out in anger and rage very suddenly, when the victim will try to confront or contradict you. But remember, this anger doesn't generate from out-of-control nerve. It is "controlled anger". In most cases, it shock the victim into fright and submission. Don't continue it very long. Give him few moments of relief in the midst of anger. The victim will long to see your charming and deceptive sweetness. Victims lose courage to challenge the manipulator after few such incidents. One more thing you have to remember. Manipulators have no conscience or sympathy for their victims. So, during confrontrations, victim uses his morality and strength as weapons. In the other hand, you'll use lies, deception, shaming, controlled anger, emotional blackmail etc. about which innocent victims have little idea. So, you have the dark qualities to break the victim into submisson. You just have to use these ruthlessly. Through this process, you will be able to break his free spirit. When a sense of helplessness and hopelessness will pervade him, you'll know that you have succeded. He is virtually your hostage now, at your mercy and complete domination. He'll do whatever you want. CAUTION. Manipulators are not insane psychopaths. Never use these skills for fun or to just hurt someone. Control freaks do that, not clever manipulators. To be a master manipulator, you have to be cold, ruthless, selfish, shrewd person, not necessarily a mental abuser.

Manipulation is all about understanding and leveraging psychology. And psychological forces affect us every day. Here are some good psychology tactics you can use. However, these can be used for good and evil. I am in no way promoting persuasion tactics for evil. Don’t use these to take advantage of people. Be responsible and use these powerful principles for good. Stand out and give people a clear, vivid image of yourself or the time you spent with them. People remember the beginning and the end of something (eg number sequence, shopping list, etc.) the clearest. The middle, however, is where things might tend to get forgotten. If your setting up a time for an interview, make sure you’re either interviewed first or last. If you’re going on a date, pick the beginning or the end of the day. And, whilst on the date, make sure to set a strong impression for the beginning and end of the date.If you want to build people’s trust more quickly, mirroring can be very effective. When you’re striking up a conversation, subtly mirror their body language. Subtly mirroring people’s body language subconsciously makes them think you’re in sync, which works very well for building trust.If you’re on a date, and you choose an activity that involves an adrenaline rush. This will help stimulate arousal in the brain, and make the other person believe they are really enjoying their time with you. They will attribute the cause the emotional peak to their attraction to you.If you think someone doesn’t like you, ask them for a small favor, like borrowing their pen. Even if they’re inclined to say no, asking to borrow a pen is such a small favor, that it’s incredibly hard for anyone to say no to that. After accepting your request for a small favor, he will eventually come to the conclusion that you’re okay after all. This is often dubbed the Benjamin Franklin Effect, as he deployed it regularly.If you have a friend that struggles to open up to you, tell you how their feeling. Ask a question, and if they respond partially, or it feels like they’re hiding something, simply keep eye contact and remain silent for a few seconds. The silence combined with eye contact will make them uncomfortable. They’ll talk to break this tension, even if that means giving you the information they were holding back.To find out if a person likes you, pick a word and every time he/she uses this word or synonymous word phrases, nod and smile. If he/she does like you, watch him/her start using the word all the time.Do you want people to take your words seriously? Every time you tell them something, say that your father taught you this. People tend to believe parents’ advice inherently.Become an ultimate ‘Rock, paper, scissors’ champion! To win at the ‘Rock, Paper, Scissors’ game, right before playing it, ask your opponent a random question. Most of the time your confused friend will throw ‘scissors.’If you want people to agree with you, just nod and maintain eye contact while you’re talking. The “nodding” action makes the person start to believe what you’re saying is actually true, and therefore they will most likely begin to nod as well, and agree with you. Plus, following social behavior patterns, people tend to nod back.Have you ever wished the subway wasn’t that crowded in the morning? In crowded places look right in front of you, in the direction in which you’re going. You will be impressed watching the crowd literally give way to you. This trick is very easy to explain: in crowded places we tend to look other people in the eyes so that we know which direction someone is going. We take the opposite way so not to run into each other.If a certain song is stuck in your head and you would love to forget it, try to think of the end of the song. According to the Zeigarnik effect, our brain tends to remember the things that we’ve left unfinished. So if you think of the end of the annoying earworm, you will be able to get it out of your head.If you have the feeling that someone is watching you, just yawn and look around. If someone is really stalking you, they will yawn too, since yawning is highly contagious. Looking at your watch also works.Your friend will most likely help you carry, let’s say, a box of your stuff if you continue talking while handing over the box. The majority of people won’t even notice you’re handing them something and will take it. However, some people more attentive and less close to you may get pretty confused.Whatever your friend has just said, paraphrase it and say it again. The person who talks to you will subconsciously get the feeling you are a really great listener. Just don’t go too far with the paraphrasing thing.If you want someone to help you, start your phrase with the words ‘I need your help...’ People hate feeling guilty and that’s why they won’t be able to refuse to help. Also, be sure to use the word “because.” Simple adding that one word let’s people know that there a good reason, making them more included to help.If you believe a person doesn’t like you, ask if you can borrow his pencil or pen. On one hand, people tend not to help those whom they don’t like, but on the other hand, it’s such a small favor that your ‘hater’ most likely won’t be able to say ‘No’. Eventually he will come to the conclusion that you’re not that bad.Women who smile are more attractive. Men who smile less and appear serious are more attractive. Attractive equals charisma and makes it easier for you to use psychological techniques on your target.Never shake hands with someone if your hands are cold. If you know you’re going to shake hands with someone, make sure your hands are warm. Warm hands promote a friendly atmosphere while cold handshaking will trigger the opposite effect.Find a point of affinity. Now, you two are part of an “in group.” It’s human nature to seek out like-minded individuals, and because we view them to be like us, we automatically trust them more. This creates an us-versus-them mentality. Standing against something can be just as powerful in marketing as standing for something.Let them talk about themselves. This is classic networking advice, but it works, even when the other person is aware of this effect, which is why I love it so much. Results showed that the brain regions associated with motivation and reward were most active when participants were sharing information publicly — but also when they were talking about themselves, even if no one was listening.What are your favorites?  Related: How can I learn to read people?  If you like this, check out some of my other Quora answers: What is one piece of advice that you've read in a book that has stuck with you for life?What is the most complex thing in psychology you have learned?Thanks!  If that was helpful, please follow me on Quora.

Yes I do . I am gonna tell you one of them . This is called Suprise effect .It is widely used in psychotherapy .I think it was first used by famous American psychiatrist Milton Erickson . It is also used in Hypnosis Induction. Ok. Here ‘s how it works. Confuse first and suggest second . Your friend might say “My life isn’t worth living!” You reply. “Yes, you are absolutely right! (surprising agreement)… Your life isn’t worth living… the way you’ve been living it up to now… and that’s why we are going to start making positive changes right this instant…”(suggestion). Humour is the best shock of all. Here’s another example. Client comes to therapy and She needed investigative surgery and was very worried that she might ‘be aware and feel everything, but not be able to move’ while under the anesthetic.After therapist having established excellent rapport with her, he didn’t try to argue with her about this, but went for the humorous approach instead. “I think that is incredibly unlikely! In fact, I think it’s so unlikely that, if you tell me it did happen, I will run naked through Churchill Square (a local shopping mall). That’s how unlikely I think it is!” The shock, he gave her with his bet helped deliver a new frame of reference that put her anxiety in perspective and enabled her to go calmly through the surgery – noticing nothing, of course. So unexpected agreement, confusion and humor can quickly open minds to new ideas. Just remember not to overdo it with shock – otherwise you will lose the element of surprise! I wanna give you another example which was used by great psychiatrist Milton Erickson . A young couple who couldn’t conceive came to see the great Dr Erickson. They were very proper, articulate, college professors, very serious. They described how they had failed to produce children. As Erickson recorded: “They spoke only in polysyllabic words, and whenever possible used clinical medical terms.” After listening to their account, Erickson said he believed that they could be cured by shock therapy. If they agreed to this, they must further agree that, following their shock, they must return home in complete silence, so that the effects of the shock would not be diluted. Somewhat bemused, the couple agreed. Erickson then had them grasp the arms of the chair, ready to receive their shock therapy (expectation is a powerful prelude to hypnosis). Looking at them squarely, he then said: “You have been engaged in marital union with full physiological concomitants to fulfill your philoprogenitive desires. Now, why in hell don’t you go fuck for fun, and pray to the devil she isn’t knocked up for at least three months! Now please leave!” Three months later, the wife was pregnant. Suprise Effect is just the one of mind tricks you can use to influence people or in some cases manipulate them as well. Human brain has the capacity to generate approximately 23 watts of power when awake. For more info, check out My profile Bio

When persuading somebody, use their name in the middle of the request, especially if they’re not very close to you. This is an amazing trick. It works because people feel the need to be acknowledged. Once they are, they will be way more unlikely to be disagreeable with you.Touching the shoulder. That’s the same reasoning as before, but more bold. Also, more effective if it works. It’s all about proximity and acknowledgment.When you want to convince somebody else, if you nod your head some times while talking, that person will be more likely to accept what you’re saying as true.When you’re saying something that is very serious, look straight into their eyes and don’t look away (but blink, the idea is not to look like a psychopath).Complement somebody about how impressive is what they are doing for you. This is the oldest trick in the world, except if you ask a question. People love to talk about themselves. Asking about how they learned to do that keeps them bragging while you get your stuff done :)This is one of my favorites. When Obama was debating Mitt Romney, there’s this moment when Romney brings up Obama’s pension. While he’s doing this, Obama ignores him, smiles and forces Romney to repeat the question several times. This is an amazing domination technique - it made Romney seem like he was begging for attention. Another one about dominance, if you start talking to somebody, get them engaged and then in the middle ask for his or her name again, as if you forgot. It puts people very uncomfortable around you, but keep in mind this might be not so cool if you don’t do it naturally.This one is to screw someone else in an argument. When somebody finishes talking, don’t answer. They are probably going to keep talking to fill the silence, which will make them look like they are not in control of the conversion.

"Help advance someone's goals to get them to do you a favor." It's a bit calculating, but it's right out of Zig Ziglar: “You will get all you want in life, if you help enough other people get what they want."Tweak the environment to get people to act less selfishly." Asking favors in a social setting rather than a business setting makes people more inclined to act like a friend than a business rival.“Use a decoy option to get people to buy your product." Trying to get people to buy a more expensive version of your product? Introduce a third option—one that's the same price, but less effective."Focus on what your bargaining partner is gaining, not losing." Sounds fair, but if you're hiding that you're offering someone a bad deal, I hope you're doing something else to balance out your karma."Mimic people's body language to get them to like you." Research suggests if copy their body language, others are more likely to identify with you subconsciously. And that makes them more likely to do what you want."Display an image of eyes to get people to behave ethically." When we see eyes, we feel like we're being watched, and we feel whatever we do will be observed and judged."Use nouns instead of verbs to get people to change their behavior." People think about their self-identities when they hear nouns. When they hear verbs, they think of behavior. Nouns win."Speak quickly to get an argument opponent to agree with you." Overwhelm people your speed, and wear them down. They'll sometimes agree because they can't process what you're saying - and they don't want to admit it."Ask people for favors when they're tired to get them to cooperate." Similar to a few other ideas on the list, when people are worn down they're more likely to agree. Car dealers use this tactic—it's why it's so hard to simply show up and get a quote."Scare people to get them to give you what you need." This is the core of most advertising - make people fear something, and then sell them the antidote."Confuse people to get them to comply with your request." People don't want to admit they don't understand things, so they agree. The example given is to describe the price of something in pennies, rather than dollars, since it takes longer to process.

A2ASo you wish to learn to manipulate people eh? Learn the precious dark arts that the rich, the powerful, and the well connected have been using to control society for years? Well come sit by the fire child- and let me tell you about power. I go in depth in my other answers about learning the dark arts but here's a brief crash course to learn: Purchase the 48 Laws of Power by Robert Greene. I recommend this book for a few reasons: A) If you're asking this question you are most likely not manipulative or a cold hearted person- and need to learn. B) You are starting off handicapped in the real world. You do not posses the sight, as I call it, to truly see those around you. Finally C) This book will make you conscious. Conscious of not only the world- but the true nature of others.After each Law you learn and acquire go into a social environment (work, school, crowded cafe etc.) and do one of two things: A) Try a Law on an unsuspecting victim, and learn how to use the Law efficiently. B) Observe your environment and watch the Law(s) be enacted (trust me you will see at least one).In order to manipulate others- you first need to understand how you- yourself- are being manipulated. I have a saying "if you ever want learn how a person will use you- look at those closest to you." Your close friends, family, hell your cute niece who you always seem to give into- observe them closely. They know all the kinks in your armor, and use them against you when they need something.Finally, one key thing I want to stress in this brief crash course- is that you have to lose your heart. Understand this key phrase: "No one has a heart like you." This means- do not expect people to care about you just because you care. People use each other often and exploit weaknesses for their own personal gain. Accept this reality and lose your heart that blinds your cold hard logic.This last one is just for fun. Once you've finished your journey you'll realized that people are more complex than any math equation or expression can ever be. Use your new powers wisely.***If you have any comments, questions, or just want some advice from the devil himself please feel free to message me. Happy Hunting... Edit as of 6/29/17 It has been 2 years since this post was created and over 13k of you have shown your support. Continue to forge your path of true freedom, which is the ultimate power. Arm yourself with this knowledge and your mind will be of steel. No weapon shall be formed against you. It is with this I remind you of my solemn promise, Power is your birthright. Thank you for your support, ~K.W.II~ Edit as of 9/26/2018 Use your powers carefully, my friends. True leadership is the ultimate calling.

Knowledge can be power in a circumstance. Subsequently, knowledge of psychology can also be a ‘power’ and used or restrained in any number of ways. What is next to impossible to define is the what, how and when someone with knowledge will choose to express what they know or how they use it. Ethics can be taught but, the choice to live by a set of guidelines is ultimately a personal choice. One thing to remember is so much of manipulation is around the little things through the day. If I watch myself through any given day, I certainly do my share and the majority of the time it is to make my life just a bit easier than it was before. That being said I have had some seriously manipulative people in my life from time to time and it is the bad type of manipulation which extends to being seriously unethical, if not illegal. After those types of experiences, yes I am left with the question you pose and others. Here are some of the ways people can use psychology to manipulate. The insider advantage. Taken literally, knowing more about someone else gives an immediate and tangible advantage, especially if they don’t know you know. From there the possibilities are endless as to how information can be used against someone.The Setup. Often done with insider knowledge of someone. A setup can easily be established to either reveal a weakness, secret or fear (just a few examples) in a variety of situations. I saw quite a bit of this in work situations where the social mixes with workplace hierarchy and varying personal states of individuals in a workplace and you have a recipe for… well just about anything.Emotions Say it All. So often, life can be grinding and we get lost in the day somewhere and a connection with someone often will pull us out (ooops, that may have been more autobiographical). That connection with someone can be an in to manipulate… you know save you from the day.Assumptions, assumptions. Assumptions are always a fertile ground for so many things. Add to this the use of appearances, other people’s assumptions and then throw in just enough social media and yes you can cause someone quite a bit of grief just on assuming based on appearances or what someone else says.Second hand information. This is one of the biggest ways people can be manipulated. What someone is telling you about yet someone else is the easiest way to be manipulated. There is usually a lot of pressure to just ‘go along with it’ in our social circles alone as well as professional circles. This is also an arena where some of the biggest and most painful misunderstandings. So, ask about what you are hearing or better yet go to the subject of the conversation and confirm what has been relayed.Again, this is a big arena of possibilities of how psychology can be used to manipulate you. Just don’t forget the limits of this are directly connected to the limits of human creativity.

It doesn't matter where you stand, you will rarely get benefit from the government except you stand close then you want people to know about. Life was miserable for a homeless man in the era of roosevelt or Obama. It's still going to be hard in the future. Or You don't have money ? Well, you are fucked my friend even if you share your day with buddha himself… …. You know why people love democracy more? At fundamental level every person is a politician himself/her self. Don't we like to get pramotion even after knowing we don't deserve it? Don't we like to people value us? Don't we all like that one person to fall in love with us? Don't we like to live a great life? Some of us suck at it. Some of us get lucky. Some of us fell through the cracks. Some of us didn't get rewarded even after giving everything they got. Some of us got everything for nothing. Your situation as of this moment is a reflection of your understanding of your most innate nature. I.e. politics. … You want to manipulate people? Understand their politics. Now, we dont have that much time to understand everyone so how can we effectively get the best possible value for our time? (Be selfish here, if you think then you will find how much time you wasted just to get something simple? If you selfish, you will bs people less, you will know how to declare on point and precise intention.) Let's say I want to find out who is the richest guy in the room, how do I do that giving it's my first time in the room? I will be using what i call it informative manipulation as i just want to know who is he? Point 1) Analyze the venue: is it in high end or in moderate end or in cheap end? Usually host reflects the guests he is going to have. The cost of the venue tells me what kind of rich will be a “basic reference” to find my guy. Point 2) analyze the parking lot. Expensive cars, moderate cars or cheap cars? This will give me aprx number of rich people. This will eliminate major chunk out of the equation. Point 3) analyze the seating arrangements: is it simple row or purposely designed in a way to have “exclusive" access to the view? My guy must be in that “exclusive" sitting. Point 4) analyze the food and drinks: food reflects the “fineness” of the people. It helps in cross reference to the shape of the glass holding the drink. You know the more expensive it is, the more quality glass you going to get. These points will reduce my crowd from 100 to 10. I just gotta watch who do people say more “hi" to? I will go talk to that person. I will ask him casually about his work…. Let's say the guy says he is a “lawyer" So, I will go and cross check with my four points and it makes him my guy until I find a doctor or a politician. …. You see, I just reduced my talk time in establishing myself as a new comer. I just gotta focus on him or her and preying on a chance to exploit it. ……….. If you understand the politics of the people using few simple rules, you will not even have to manipulate at all in the first place. Enjoy

One of the greatest con jobs of all time almost backfired until, with a little help, the victim convinced himself his money was safe. It wasn't. It was the year 1925, and the Eiffel Tower was falling apart. Repairing the tower would cost a ton of money and the government couldn't afford its upkeep. Victor Lustig, a veteran conman was reading a newspaper article about this situation and came up with the idea of selling the Eiffel Tower.  But how could he do that? The Eiffel Tower didn't belong to him. Since we are talking about one of the greatest conmen in history, getting a real estate authorization wasn't a big deal. He posed as a government official, gathered 20 local scrap metal dealers and told them “a secret”. The city, unable to afford the upkeep on the tower, was planning to sell it for scrap, but due to expected controversy, they want to finalize the details before announcing its plans. He offered them a chance to buy the Tower before anyone else knew it was available. With his faked documents, elegant clothing and a bit of greed, he was able to convince them he was legitimate. He secured bids from each one of them, and soon selected the "winner". It was André Poisson, a man with low self-esteem who was anxious to make a name for himself in Paris. But André became suspicious. Lustig became concerned about being caught. What should he do? Close the deal as quickly as possible? Abandon the scheme? Never. He wanted a way to get André to convince himself that Lustig was, in fact, a government official. His plan was ingenious and risky. In the next meeting, he avoided the conversation about the tower and begin talking about his financial situation. He offered André to guarantee his "contract" in return from giving him money. André came to the conclusion that he wasn't being conned, he was being asked for a bribe. He was convinced, and the deal was closed. After all, what conman asks for a bribe? Now, this reveals an interesting tendency of human nature: People sometimes believe what they are told, but never doubt what they conclude. A skilled magician by just using simple methods can trick the most brilliant audiences. By using simple props and an intriguing story, an experienced conman can fool anyone. And with proper delivery, a comedian can take a laugh from even the most serious guy. What do all these people have in common? They have mastered the art of inducing unconscious assumptions in the minds of others. When a magician shows you that there's nothing on his sleeves, he doesn't prove that. He is just leading us to assume that he's not hiding anything. It's the same strategy used by the conman. Victor Lustig not only showed fake documents, he even took his victims on a tour to the Eiffel Tower. He showed them the condition of the tower and it proved them he was legitimate. Comedians use this trick to make us laugh. E.g "My grandmother has been walking three miles a day every day for the last five years and now… we don't know where the hell she is." By reading the first part we make an assumption that she has been exercising. And once we picture that situation on our mind, the comedian explodes with the punchline, "now we don't know where the hell she is." While magicians, conmen, and comedians use this trick, only comedians reveal it on their work. These assumptions might sound silly to us in retrospect but can go unnoticed in reality. We take the information so fast and often we fail to distinguish between what's real and what we "assumed." Learn from the masters Many people today complain that entertainment has no educational value. While I agree with them, when it comes to increasing your persuasion skills, nothing could be farther from the truth. The school of entertainment is the greatest school of manipulation. Films, Tv shows, jokes, magician acts are loaded with opportunities for us to understand and become more sensitive to, how people think. The reason is that these opportunities are intentionally put there by respective creators. They know, perhaps better than anyone, how to trigger specific thoughts, feelings, and assumptions in our minds. In addition, the material is easy to understand because it's short. A comedian has a few lines to generate the effect. A songwriter has few minutes and a screenwriter has a couple of hours, at most. Their job is to make an impact in this amount of time or they've failed. Now, some people might complain, how can made up stories teach us about "real life." First of all, for an entertainment product to succeed, it needs to generate the desired effect on the largest number of people. Second, you need to see what effect has entertainment on you. Have you ever laughed, cried, or felt fear by just watching a movie? Was that real or you were making it up? Case closed. We can learn a lot by just paying more attention to how movies cause emotions. We can uncover the underlying psychological secrets that made the reaction not only possible but almost inevitable. Check Out: q/persuasionDo you know a psychological trick to manipulate others?Sources: “Forbidden keys to persuasion” by Blair WarrenThe conman who sold the Eiffel Tower twice

Here are just a couple: Getting you to feel that the blame is on YOU, not on them. YOU are guilty for their actions. For example, a man who cheats on a woman will say, “It’s because I need more attention and affection, and you’re not giving it to me, so I had to go somewhere else to find it.” Changing topics when confronted. A woman was confronting her husband for the poor way in which he treated her kids. He then, out of the blue, started talking to her about how she had owls and Buddhas and candles in her house and how it was a sign of witchcraft (it was not- it was just decoration, and she also had many Christian symbols in her house). Using a person’s compassion card. I share legal custody of two kids with another woman (they were my unofficial foster kids for 8 years full-time). Recently, the whole family moved close to me from several states away (my boys went back to live full-time with their bio mom about 5 years ago). She will often not actually ask for things, but go on and on about how much she needs “x” so when I then help with “x” and later confront her about it when she asks for MORE things, she’ll say, “I never ASKED you to help me. That was YOUR choice.” Therefore, she doesn’t have to accept responsibility for it. She also plays the “Oh, this would be so good for the boys,” or “I’m so sad that I can’t get this for the boys” card. Or, when I say no, “You never cared about me! You only want to help the boys, not me!” Or “You helped me before! Why is it such a big deal now?” She also has a habit of not planning ahead, so everything is an emergency and then if I don’t help, terrible things happen- the electric will get cut off or there will be no TP in the house or whatever. Or she plays the “Well, you promised when we moved up here FOR YOU that you’d help us with everything we needed,” as if that means she doesn’t have to do anything to provide for herself. Or she’ll promise how she’s going to pay me back, but then something always comes up and I won’t get paid back. Or she’ll play the “Oh, you help everyone else but you won’t help us,” card. Or the “But you’re the only one I have,” card. You get the idea. I’ve had to learn to set up healthy boundaries because many thousands of dollars in debt later, I just can’t keep giving into an empty hole. Working in a helping profession, I have people ask me for help all the time. I’ve learned that people will often lie or mislead to get what they want. They say they have children that are hungry and they need money for food. When I offer them food, they say they need milk or meat. When I offer them gift certificates with “food only” marked on them from the local grocery store, they don’t show up to pick them up. They will go on and on about how they need help paying for this or that bill, often mentioning having a child. Often they want cash, but, of course, have no plans on using it for the bills. Or I find out that they have cable and an expensive cell phone or beer in their trunk, etc. (but they can’t pay their electric). Or they’re on drugs. Or they’ll get food from us and then sell it. People are really good at pushing on one’s heartstrings. Another tactic is fear. The scammers who call saying they’re from the IRS and will come and arrest you are one example. Another example is a woman who keeps telling her boyfriend, “I will leave you if you don’t buy me ‘x’.” Another tactic is flattery. This is the tactic that catfishers use online. They suck you in by complimenting you and making you feel good about yourself, but it’s all for a selfish reason. We all have people like that in our lives to some extent, I think. They make us feel good about ourselves so that they can get something from us. There are so many examples of manipulation. I think you could spend a lifetime studying manipulation tactics and still not know them all.

A lot of people do this one trick, and most often they aren't aware of doing it because it's a subconscious habit they have developed which is caused by low self-esteem, unhealthy ego attachment and neediness. It's called undermining. To undermine someone means to plant seeds of self-doubt in their minds in an attempt to make you dependent on them, weaken you, control you and to gain power over you. Some examples of undermining are: Negging. Negging is basically emotional manipulation, and it’s purpose is to undermine a persons confidence and to increase their need for the manipulator's approval.Belittling someone. This may happen in the form of spreading false rumors about you, gossip or accusing you of not being good enough despite this not being the case.Focusing on your flaws more than on your strengths. This happens entirely because of someones unhealthy ego attachment. If they focus on your strengths and skills which may be better than theirs, they would feel powerless and inferior to you. Focusing on your flaws on the other hand makes them feel superior to you and that gives them a sense of control.Setting others up against you. I found that this happens when someone cannot cope with the pain caused by rejection or a break up. It happened to me many years ago. When I broke up with my then girlfriend, she became mad, started telling her girlfriends and every other girl she knew that I am an asshole and even spread lies about me that made her girlfriends hate me. Some time later I got emails from them whose contents were full of nasty insults and stuff. All because my ex was unable to accept I didn't love her anymore. This is yet another defense mechanism caused by unhealthy ego attachment and its purpose is to gain control over someone or over a situation.A commitment to misunderstand you. Sometimes, people are so full of hate and resentment that they cannot interpret correctly what you say and do. They will always misunderstand it and manipulate or distort the truth, so they can spread blame and hate everywhere.

20 simple psychological tricks to influence people  1. Ask a question and wait There is an old trick used by interrogators, inspectors and auditors, which is to ask a question and then remain silent, without losing eye contact. This causes the other party to start talking and provide more information. 2. Get without resistance  If someone is talking in an exalted or worried way about something, you just have to extend your hand and it will automatically hand you everything that is holding at that moment without realizing it. 3. Don't blame people, blame the situation Prevent others from getting mad at you in a very simple way: don't use the word "you." Don't blame anyone directly, blame the situation you're talking about. The correct words in the correct order influence the decisions of others. 4. Offer alternatives Always look for a plan "B" to problems. This makes your interlocutor begin to guide his path, believing that he is in control of the situation. 5 Less critical Start using plural terms, for example: instead of saying "don't do this" say "let's not do this". By speaking this way, we make it seem like someone else is breaking the rules, and at the same time, we make sure that whoever really does it does not feel criticized. 6. Silent interruptions If a person does not let you speak or give an opinion, subtly throw something away (keys, pen, notebook). Bend down to pick it up and start talking. It is a way to interrupt without the other person noticing. 7. Imitation with reward When you want to enlist someone's help, try to discreetly imitate their movements and postures during the conversation; This creates a false sense of familiarity. Remember to do it in a subtle way, otherwise you might take it in a not so pleasant way. 8. Empathize with anger If you want to calm someone down, seek empathy with their feelings. It doesn't matter if it's anger, pay attention to what they are saying and let them know that you understand, that they have the right to be angry, and that it is okay to be upset. As you accept the situation, the emotion and anger that invade you will disappear. 9. Learn to negotiate without contracts It doesn't matter if it's a raise, homework, or the price of a car, visibly shrink your figure for the first two offers and use a pained gesture, sigh, or a drop of the eyes. This gesture causes that most of the time they lower or raise the initial offer depending on what you negotiate. 10. Avoid confusion Forget unnecessary dances when walking on the sidewalk. Intentionally look over the shoulder of the person coming towards you; that way, your gaze shows him where you are going and that will make him move to the opposite side. 11. Glances that catch When you meet someone you like, look at the color of their eyes and then smile a little. This type of glances causes people to respond delightedly. 12. Address people by name By addressing people by name you will make them warmer, as an immediate bond of trust and friendship is created, although it may not work with someone very formal. 13 Less nerves, more gum Apparently when we eat something, the brain sends the signal that we are safe. For this reason, you should have a chewing gum on hand and use it at the right time. 14. Remember that silence is worth gold When someone says something to you that bothers you, just turn around and be silent. People are uncomfortable with silence and will often end up apologizing to avoid discomfort. 15. Gradual commitment People will agree to do what you ask if you ask for something easier first. 16. Warm hands Try to keep your hands warm before shaking them; you'll make a more positive impression and have a better chance that people will want to be with you. 17. Asking for favors makes you more attractive Ask him to do you a small favor; He'll think you like him just because he's willing to do you a favor. 18. Take advantage of fatigue When people are tired, their defenses are low and they are more willing to listen. It is the best time to request something without having to force the situation. 19. Recognize the enemy Find out who is following in your footsteps in a very simple way: just yawn and look at the people around you. Since yawning is contagious, you will immediately know who is watching you. 20. Smile A frank smile will always be the best of all weapons, because when we do, we transmit happiness, confidence and well-being to others. Go to my profile to visit my blog for reading some more useful and informative article.

Manipulation has gotten a bad rap. Most people hear the word and think ill intent is involved. That can be the case — manipulating a person in a way that they do something that they will later regret — but most manipulation is fairly benign. All manipulation is increasing the chance that the other person will do something that you want them to do; that doesn’t necessarily mean they will live to regret that. When I was a kid and wanted to do something or go somewhere, I asked my mother, because she was much more likely to give approval than if I asked my father. There were times when my father found out later and told my mother she should have involved him in the decision. She might then tell me that she was OK with it but “ask your father”. I would timidly approach Dad and he would ask me, “What did your mother say.”, and I would exuberantly tell him that Mom thought it was a good idea (more than her OK). He was more likely to consent if he knew that Mom had already given approval, though he might set limits upon how long I could be gone, who I was with and that I must call and let them know why I was delayed. When Mom knew I or my siblings really wanted to do something . . It was important to us . . She would tell us, “Let me talk to your father”, so she could tell him at a time and in a way that was mostly likely to get his consent. She would tell us that she wouldn’t ask him now because he was tired or upset about something and would not respond well to the request. She would wait for a time when he was relaxed and in a better mood. All of this is benign manipulation: Asking Mom first, telling Dad that Mom already gave enthusiastic consent, and have Mom intercede to approach Dad when he was mostly likely to give his consent. There are all kinds of daily situations that involve such mild manipulations: A neighbor comes over to chat with you before saying what he really wants from you. At church or a civic organization, a member smiled and calls you by first name, then implores you to help with a fund-raising or service event. At work, co-workers (some of whom you may not even know) need something from you and they approach in a cheerful and complimentary manner, followed by asking your help (you’d be such a dear to) with some project or task. They usually come prepared to tell you how you would benefit from involvement in the task, if only via the knowledge that it helps the organization or fellow co-workers. Successful salespeople are very skilled in how to persevere through people’s hesitance and persuade you that you stand to benefit in exchange for “just a minute of your time”. They know how to push enough to defeat resistance and then let up when the resistance becomes firm. They know that if they leave on good terms with you, perhaps leave literature so that you are thinking of the product or service after they leave, and then suggest they will check back with you at a better time, there is a potential sale there. It’s persistence combined with making appeals to people’s weak spots (especially their desire to be nice and reasonable) that helps the manipulator reach their objective.

If you have to make a critic to someone, try to sandwich it between two positive facts about them in this order [ Positive / Negative / Positive]. They tend to be received better this way.You're arguing about whether blue or red is a better colour. Just say "blue is a fantastic colour, but I think red is a bit better, though I like blue too" as opposed to "blue sucks, red rules". If you need help with work, saying “I need your help” is sufficient to get them on board. It makes them feel needed and like they are making a difference.If someone keeps asking “why” and you’re not sure what to say, ask them "I'm not sure, what do you think?"They answer their own question, you provide some feedback "Sounds good to me." and they immediately move on.If you want extra information about something, let the person keep speaking without being pushy about it. If they stop, just wait. They will continue speaking & adding to what they were saying to fill the silence.Be nice, even to mean people. It's kinda fun seeing someone initially angry soften when you don't give in to anger.When somebody shy is speaking, if you look at them and nod your head it encourages them to keep talking.Instead of asking "Do you have any questions?" I ask "What questions do you have?"The first almost always results in silence, and the second lets people feel comfortable to ask questions.If you need to remember something, think about it while doing something noticeably unusual. It pairs the memory with the "something" and will trigger that particular memory.Need to take out the garbage before going to bed? Put your pillow at the foot of your bed.If someone is obviously rude, don’t insult them. Just say you really like when they are nice to you. They can't really call you out on it and it makes them realize their behaviour.Sources: [1]

The principle of reciprocation. A few days back, my very fine friend wanted to borrow some money from me, I don’t want to disclose the amount, but it is a 4digit figure.  source:unsplashed.com The thing is I didn't have enough funds with me I had barely the amount he asked and for my expense for that month, I was reluctant yet I gave him what he asked. Why?? I asked myself, I knew I wouldn’t get it anytime soon. ( he still hasn’t returned it yet, and I am close to broke now) But, if it was someone else I wouldn’t have given it, but to him, I had to give despite the logical decision was not to lend him any money. Here’s why about a year ago I was broke and desperate, I ran to many for money and also had to run to him, I asked him for a 4 digit sum, l he was one among the significant few who helped me and saved me a great deal during that time. So when he asked for some money the other day, I simply had to give it to him, because otherwise, it felt wrong … somehow… This is my - life -an example of the “Law of Reciprocation”… Well, many people use this purposefully to you knowingly or unknowingly, especially those sellers who give us free sample, the people who simply offer us help, the unsuspecting guy at the office who shows an additional intention fo helping you at something, the cab driver asking for 10bucks less than the original cab fare, the vegetable lenders who give us extra tomatoes and etc..etc… I don’t mean that everybody is dishonest, (even my fine friend wasn’t dishonest, he helped me at the right time and am thankful to him always), my point is that the inner feeling you have inside when you become an unsuspecting victim of the “law of reciprocation”, is something to be controlled if you don't want to be overused by people. Watch out, Dan Edward

“I am sorry. I know I did wrong and it’s not justifiable. But I want to improve and I am aware of what I did but I just need another chance. You are my friend, you’ve stood by my side even after all these years and deep down I know you’ll help me…” All of us are naive at some point of our lives. So Story time- Jake, a junior used to talk to me and my friends. Now he was very good at giving advises and playing the role of a good friend in a need. But soon after he tells my friend ( Let’s call her Amy) that he likes her. Now Amy is the prettiest of our bunch and since we are so protective of her, we told her that he is just physically attracted to her. She agreed and light conversations went on. But then he casts the magical spell: flattery. And he got her. Now they are happily dating while I am still sure he is just a fake guy. We warn her, she tells us stuff about how he is a troubled kid at home, how he is trying to improve himself and how pathetic his life is. You know the usual? But then like it happens, he cheats. we all know it was coming. He cheated with on Amy with his best friend. All good? No one knows, it’s been going on for months Amy is happy, Jake is happy, and so is his best friend because of the false promises Jake made to both of them. But then all of it came into light. Explosions of truth, lie, betrayal, tears happens and then he says this- “I am sorry. I know I did wrong and it’s not justifiable. But I want to improve and I am aware of what I did but I just need another chance. You are my friend, you’ve stood by my side even after all these years and deep down I know you’ll help me…” Now obviously he’ll call us his friends because of those small smooth conversations we used to have. Amy being the kind- hearted person, melted. This won’t even look like manipulation, because he was a troubled kid but that’s exactly how he did it. TLDR; He won her sympathy, not only hers, but his friends’ too, by depicting himself as a troubled person. He apologized and behaved as a good person so everyone would still have some hope for him. He took the blame and played the “I want to improve” and “You are my friend” cards. And he made us feel guilty (not me because I never liked him) that he is so troubled and we just couldn’t help him. Guilt tripping the person is the best way to manipulate him/her. Not everyone out here is insensitive and most of us wants to look at a person beyond his flaw, which makes us more susceptible to their manipulation. The best way to deal with them, is to observe their tactics and then question them subtly, and eventually they will come around.

Evеr thought about uѕіng рѕусhоlоgу tо уоur bеnеfіt уоur еvеrуdау interactions wіth оthеrѕ? Yоu dоn’t need a рѕусh degree, nоr do уоu need аnу mind-reading аbіlіtіеѕ. I сlеаrlу еxрlаіnеd mоrе аbоut рѕусhоlоgісаl trісkѕ hеrе.  In оur соuntlеѕѕ іntеrасtіоnѕ wіth frіеndѕ, соwоrkеrѕ, аnd superiors, we hаvе thе ability tо mаnірulаtе the ѕіtuаtіоn аnd capitalize оn thеѕе ѕосіаl exchanges. Whеn I say mаnірulаtе, I dоn’t nесеѕѕаrіlу mеаn it іn a nеgаtіvе sense. Mаnірulаtіоn can bе uѕеd for gооd — соnvіnсіng ѕоmеоnе to take a vасаtіоn оr dоіng everything роѕѕіblе to gеt thаt рrоmоtіоn аt wоrk. Below аrе ѕеvеrаl wауѕ іn whісh a mеrе аwаrеnеѕѕ оf the рѕусhоlоgу bеhіnd оur іntеrасtіоnѕ can hеlр benefit uѕ more than wе wоuld еvеr еxресt. 1. Use Bоdу Lаnguаgе Tо Yоur Advаntаgе The wау thе brаіn ѕtіmulаtеѕ physical mоvеmеntѕ аnd rеасtіоnѕ durіng day-to-day іntеrасtіоnѕ is аlmоѕt unсоntrоllаblе. This tуре оf movement саn ѕіgnаl a lоt tо thоѕе аrоund you. What does thаt mean? It mеаnѕ that уоu саn uѕе body language tо undеrѕtаnd things thаt wоrdѕ wоn’t tеll you, or еvеn іnfluеnсе ѕоmеоnе wіth mоrе thаn juѕt wоrdѕ. I’m sure уоu’vе hеаrd that 90 реr сеnt of communication іѕ nоn-vеrbаl (hаrd tо bеlіеvе, but іt’ѕ actually 93 реr сеnt), meaning thаt ѕо much іn our іntеrасtіоnѕ can bе lоѕt just because we asked fоr thаt рrоmоtіоn wіth our arms crossed while lооkіng аt thе floor. Lеаrnіng to read bоdу language is juѕt аѕ іmроrtаnt аѕ properly conveying іt — іt’ll tеll уоu іf someone is gеnuіnеlу аgrееіng wіth you, асtіvеlу еngаgеd іn whаt уоu’rе ѕауіng, оr еvеn іf thеу thіnk уоu’rе a соmрlеtе idiot. Persistently picking uр оn thе body language of оthеrѕ wіll hеlр уоu іmрrоvе уоur own аbіlіtіеѕ and іdеntіfу орроrtunіtіеѕ as wеll as dеаd еndѕ for еvеrу іntеrасtіоn. Doing thіngѕ lіkе mіmісkіng роѕturеѕ, gеѕturеѕ, аnd mоvеmеntѕ can hеlр gеt someone tо lіkе уоu оr аgrее wіth уоu. Nоddіng уоur hеаd “yes” whеn уоu rеаllу mеаn “nо” can іnсrіmіnаtе you — interrogators rеlу on body lаnguаgе to dеtеrmіnе culpability on a rеgulаr basis. Wе’rе аll аnіmаlѕ аnd bеhаvе аѕ ѕuсh whеn ѕtrірреd аwау from оur mоrе ѕорhіѕtісаtеd fоrm of communication, the trісk іѕ tо use this ѕubсоnѕсіоuѕ іntеrасtіоn tо уоur bеnеfіt. Some interesting fасtѕ about body language: Oреn palms create a ѕеnѕе оf truѕt: Legoland workers are not аllоwеd tо роіnt. Inѕtеаd, thеу оffеr dіrесtіоnѕ bу using upward-facing hаnd gеѕturеѕ. Shaking hаndѕ wіth уоur palm fасіng dоwnwаrd signifies dominance аnd, with уоur palm fасіng uрwаrdѕ, ѕubmіѕѕіvеnеѕѕ. Whеn lаughіng in a grоuр, the fіrѕt person you make еуе соntасt wіth іѕ the оnе уоu truѕt thе mоѕt 2. Change Thе Pеrѕресtіvе Clоаk the rеаlіtу of thоѕе уоu’rе аttеmрtіng tо manipulate wіth a rеаlіtу thаt уоu’vе wеаvеd — gо matrix оn thеіr mіndѕ. This one’s аbоut tact, сunnіng ability, and mоѕt іmроrtаntlу, rhеtоrіс. “Mу саr only hаѕ x mіlеаgе, nеvеr you mіnd thе ruѕt spots…” “Mу bаd grаdеѕ and асаdеmіс рrоbаtіоn іn sophomore уеаr, contrasted tо thе better grаdеѕ іn mу ѕеnіоr уеаr, ѕhоw hоw muсh I’ve іmрrоvеd ѕіnсе then.” And thе сlаѕѕіс: “Thіѕ hоmе іѕ a rеаl fіxеr-uрреr — thіnk оf the роtеntіаl.” Wе dо thіѕ еvеrу dау — turnіng hаlf-еmрtу glаѕѕеѕ on their sides. A lоt of the time, реrѕресtіvе can really mean a wоrld оf difference іn thе way thаt ѕоmеоnе looks аt ѕоmеthіng. Thіѕ perspective іtѕеlf саn be іnfluеnсеd by уоur descriptions. Rhetoric is a crucial fасtоr thаt underlies this nоtіоn as іt encompasses ѕо many аѕресtѕ beyond just what wаѕ said аnd hоw it wаѕ ѕаіd. It relies оn tоnе, соntеnt, аnd арреаlѕ to rеаѕоn, character, оr emotion. Uѕе rhеtоrіс tо bе аѕ реrѕuаѕіvе аѕ роѕѕіblе, exaggerate whеn рrасtісаl, аnd shift fосuѕ where necessary. Put thоught into hоw your аrgumеntѕ are structured аnd dеlіvеrеd, whether thеу appeal tо someone’s еmоtіоn or lоgіс. Do уоu ѕоund lіkе you know what you’re tаlkіng about еvеn whеn you don’t? If you can’t соnvіnсе ѕоmеоnе tо ѕtор wаѕtіng paper bесаuѕе оf еnvіrоnmеntаl rеаѕоnѕ, can you convince them wіth a flawlessly lоgісаl аrgumеnt as tо hоw less рареr mеаnѕ lеѕѕ work? Thinking оutѕіdе thе bоx аnd rе-frаmіng a реrѕресtіvе оn аnу given ѕіtuаtіоn can dо you good іn hоw уоu ѕее thіngѕ fоr уоurѕеlf and can аlѕо buіld on the efficacy of any argument уоu put fоrwаrd. Sоmе fасtѕ to рut this into реrѕресtіvе: Cоnvіnсіng yourself thаt you ѕlерt wеll thе previous nіght trісkѕ уоur mіnd into thіnkіng уоu did (оthеrwіѕе known аѕ “placebo sleep”). Thе Dunning Krugеr Effect: ѕmаrt people tеnd tо undеrеѕtіmаtе thеmѕеlvеѕ while іgnоrаnt реорlе tеnd tо thіnk they’re brilliant. Studіеѕ have рrоvеn thаt your fаvоrіtе ѕоng is lіkеlу associated wіth an еmоtіоnаl event іn your past. 3. Leverage Yоur Knоwlеdgе Of Othеrѕ Rely on реорlе’ѕ рѕусhоlоgісаl nееdѕ аnd use thеm аѕ a pressure роіnt. Thіѕ mіght bе a nееd to соnfоrm, tо bе ассерtеd or included, оr thе соmрlеtе орроѕіtе — the nееd tо ѕtаnd out аnd ѕwіm аgаіnѕt thе сurrеnt. The rіѕkу dесіѕіоn maker саn bе gоаdеd іntо mаkіng a рооr dесіѕіоn, thе ԛuіеt сrоwd dweller саn bе dіѕсоurаgеd from рurѕuіng anything thаt wоuld lеаd thеm аѕtrау frоm thе comforts оf соnfоrmіtу. Their weakness is your ѕtrеngth, іt’ѕ just a mаttеr оf fіgurіng оut hоw to hаrnеѕѕ thаt tо уоur аdvаntаgе. Arе thеу рrоnе tо оvеrсоnfіdеnсе thаt can саuѕе them tо ѕtumblе? Arе thеу іnѕесurе about ѕоmеthіng that саn help уоu mаkе a соnvіnсіng роіnt? Evеrуоnе hаѕ thеіr kryptonite. Thе more уоu lеаrn about someone’s рѕусhоlоgісаl tеndеnсіеѕ, mоdеѕ оf thоught, and сhаrасtеrіѕtісѕ, the mоrе of an аdvаntаgе уоu саn gаіn оvеr thеіr thоughtѕ and уоur оvеrаll іnfluеnсе оn ѕаіd thоughtѕ. Thе key to ѕuссеѕѕ here is knоwlеdgе. Like every other роіnt, іt mау be more crucial tо undеrѕtаnd your оwn pressure роіntѕ. A ѕоlіd defence іnсludеѕ аn асknоwlеdgеmеnt оf уоur own іnѕесurіtіеѕ and vulnеrаbіlіtіеѕ Psychologist Jim Snіесhоwѕkі details thе hоw-tо’ѕ of emotional leveraging whіlѕt аlѕо shining a роѕіtіvе lіght оn thе subject in hіѕ аrtісlе: Emоtіоnаl Lеvеrаgіng: It’ѕ Really Not Mаnірulаtіоn? In іt, he рrоvіdеѕ thrее bаѕіс guіdеlіnеѕ tо achieve utmоѕt success whеn uѕіng someone’s emotions against thеm: Rеmаіn аwаrе that thеіr vіѕіоn is the рrоduсt оf аn еmоtіоnаl bаѕе аnd, nо mаttеr how thеу rationalize thеіr роѕіtіоn, thеу сlіng tо іt for ѕоmе emotional rеаѕоn; See thаt if уоu want them mоvе іn уоur direction, уоur tаѕk іѕ tо dіѕсоvеr thе еmоtіоnаl vаluе thаt drives thеіr vision — thеіr sweet ѕроt; Understand thаt оnсе you knоw thеіr еmоtіоnаl sweet ѕроt, уоu саn сrаft аn аррrоасh that blеndѕ thеіr nееd wіth уоurѕ ѕо thаt уоu bоth саn fееl ѕuссеѕѕful. 4. Bе Awаrе Of Prореr Tіmіng аnd Opportunity Thе jаguаr іѕ аn effective аnd саlсulаtеd huntеr. Ancestral lеgасіеѕ оf ѕuссеѕѕ аnd fаіlurе hаvе given іt thе biological аbіlіtу оf grеаt tіmіng. It knоwѕ whеn to pounce, when tо ѕtrіkе hardest, аnd when to abort its сhаѕе. Knоw whеn tо make your mоvеѕ. Thіѕ is something wе learn frоm a young age (don’t tell mоm what уоu want fоr уоur bіrthdау whеn she’s іn a bаd mood). The trісk іѕ tо асtіvеlу mаіntаіn an аwаrеnеѕѕ and hаvе your eyes соnѕtаntlу ѕсаnnіng fоr opportunity. Silence. Silence is weird. No actions, no words - just nothing. And it is more effective than most of the tricks people have up their sleeve. We, as humans, tend to be social. On some subconscious level, we crave acceptance. And part of that is communication. You can make people guilty, anxious, defensive, aggressive, voluble simply by refusing to communicate. Stay silent. How many of your girlfriends/boyfriends have simply refused to answer your calls after an argument? It is usually effective. Not healthy, but effective. Silence can be used in a host of ways and you can generally achieve anything from your desired outcome to complete chaos. (not recommended) If you feel unsatisfied by the answer given to your question, stay silent. Research shows that nearly 85% of the people continue to elaborate their answer in this situation.All of us have used “giving the silent treatment” sometime or the other. This is one of the most basic and obvious ways to manipulate people into cooperating with you.Silence can hurt even worse than revenge. If you want to really hurt someone - ignore them. Your silence comes across as indifference - you are sending a message that the person opposite has no place in your life. They are not worthy of your time.It has been found out through research that people take the opinion of a person who speaks less much more seriously than that of a person who talks a lot. By staying silent, you can add more weight to your opinions and make them matter more.Observe a skilled public speaker. Observe the way they draw the audience in. The effectiveness of a public speaker, his ability to enthrall you does not depend upon his words, as much as it does upon his ability to pause. A rightly timed pause speaks a thousand words and by staying silent at the right time, skilled orators can move hundreds of thousands of people, they can create a sense of anticipation, longing, excitement.The list goes on. The moral is that silence is golden. But silence is also a weapon. And the people who know how to use it effectively will always hold the strings in any situation.

While manipulation is not necessarily a good thing, sometimes I see the use of being able to convince someone of something for their own good, inevitably I feel a bit guilt about it afterwards though... but anyways, basically you need to get inside the person's head. Not mess with them, but see how it is to be them. Learn as much as you can about them, their goals, their secrets, their loves, their hates, what annoys them, what they're attracted to or tugs at their heart strings. Once you've learned some of this observe how they react to things, how they think, how their logic works. Once you have a good amount of this information you can do and say things in such a way that it garners certain emotional responses from the targeted person. It's less controlling how they think and more causing them to associate what you want them to like or dislike with other things that you already know they like or dislike. This can allow you to prod them in the direction you like. Now granted this is surely not fool-proof and some people are very quick on the uptake and will see what you're doing and be wary of you in the future, so you must be very careful. I'm no mentalist, but I've done this before without negative consequences, but as others have said, if you want to prevent the possibility of negative feelings in the future, lack of trust, and guilt, and even a bit of paranoia (as you'll begin to see other people doing it, and then question everyone's motives...) you may just want to be straight-up with whoever you're trying to manipulate and come to an agreement or explain directly why you want them to think or feel a certain way about something.

Ever thought about using psychology to your benefit your everyday interactions with others? You don’t need a psych degree, nor do you need any mind-reading abilities. In our countless interactions with friends, coworkers, and superiors, we have the ability to manipulate the situation and capitalize on these social exchanges. When I say manipulate, I don’t necessarily mean it in a negative sense. Manipulation can be used for good — convincing someone to take a vacation or doing everything possible to get that promotion at work. Below are several ways in which a mere awareness of the psychology behind our interactions can help benefit us more than we would ever expect. 1. Use Body Language To Your Advantage The way the brain stimulates physical movements and reactions during day-to-day interactions is almost uncontrollable. This type of movement can signal a lot to those around you. What does that mean? It means that you can use body language to understand things that words won’t tell you, or even influence someone with more than just words. I’m sure you’ve heard that 90 per cent of communication is non-verbal (hard to believe, but it’s actually 93 per cent), meaning that so much in our interactions can be lost just because we asked for that promotion with our arms crossed while looking at the floor. Learning to read body language is just as important as properly conveying it — it’ll tell you if someone is genuinely agreeing with you, actively engaged in what you’re saying, or even if they think you’re a complete idiot. Persistently picking up on the body language of others will help you improve your own abilities and identify opportunities as well as dead ends for every interaction. Doing things like mimicking postures, gestures, and movements can help get someone to like you or agree with you. Nodding your head “yes” when you really mean “no” can incriminate you — interrogators rely on body language to determine culpability on a regular basis. We’re all animals and behave as such when stripped away from our more sophisticated form of communication, the trick is to use this subconscious interaction to your benefit. Some interesting facts about body language: Open palms create a sense of trust: Legoland workers are not allowed to point. Instead, they offer directions by using upward-facing hand gestures.Shaking hands with your palm facing downward signifies dominance and, with your palm facing upwards, submissiveness.When laughing in a group, the first person you make eye contact with is the one you trust the most2. Change The Perspective Cloak the reality of those you’re attempting to manipulate with a reality that you’ve weaved — go matrix on their minds. This one’s about tact, cunning ability, and most importantly, rhetoric. “My car only has x mileage, never you mind the rust spots…” “My bad grades and academic probation in sophomore year, contrasted to the better grades in my senior year, show how much I’ve improved since then.” And the classic: “This home is a real fixer-upper — think of the potential.” We do this every day — turning half-empty glasses on their sides. A lot of the time, perspective can really mean a world of difference in the way that someone looks at something. This perspective itself can be influenced by your descriptions. Rhetoric is a crucial factor that underlies this notion as it encompasses so many aspects beyond just what was said and how it was said. It relies on tone, content, and appeals to reason, character, or emotion. Use rhetoric to be as persuasive as possible, exaggerate when practical, and shift focus where necessary. Put thought into how your arguments are structured and delivered, whether they appeal to someone’s emotion or logic. Do you sound like you know what you’re talking about even when you don’t? If you can’t convince someone to stop wasting paper because of environmental reasons, can you convince them with a flawlessly logical argument as to how less paper means less work? Thinking outside the box and re-framing a perspective on any given situation can do you good in how you see things for yourself and can also build on the efficacy of any argument you put forward. Some facts to put this into perspective: Convincing yourself that you slept well the previous night tricks your mind into thinking you did (otherwise known as “placebo sleep”).The Dunning Kruger Effect: smart people tend to underestimate themselves while ignorant people tend to think they’re brilliant.Studies have proven that your favorite song is likely associated with an emotional event in your past.3. Leverage Your Knowledge Of Others Rely on people’s psychological needs and use them as a pressure point. This might be a need to conform, to be accepted or included, or the complete opposite — the need to stand out and swim against the current. The risky decision maker can be goaded into making a poor decision, the quiet crowd dweller can be discouraged from pursuing anything that would lead them astray from the comforts of conformity. Their weakness is your strength, it’s just a matter of figuring out how to harness that to your advantage. Are they prone to overconfidence that can cause them to stumble? Are they insecure about something that can help you make a convincing point? Everyone has their kryptonite. The more you learn about someone’s psychological tendencies, modes of thought, and characteristics, the more of an advantage you can gain over their thoughts and your overall influence on said thoughts. The key to success here is knowledge. Like every other point, it may be more crucial to understand your own pressure points. A solid defence includes an acknowledgement of your own insecurities and vulnerabilities Remain aware that their vision is the product of an emotional base and, no matter how they rationalize their position, they cling to it for some emotional reason;See that if you want them move in your direction, your task is to discover the emotional value that drives their vision — their sweet spot;Understand that once you know their emotional sweet spot, you can craft an approach that blends their need with yours so that you both can feel successful.4. Be Aware Of Proper Timing and Opportunity The jaguar is an effective and calculated hunter. Ancestral legacies of success and failure have given it the biological ability of great timing. It knows when to pounce, when to strike hardest, and when to abort its chase. Know when to make your moves. This is something we learn from a young age (don’t tell mom what you want for your birthday when she’s in a bad mood). The trick is to actively maintain an awareness and have your eyes constantly scanning for opportunity. For instance, try asking for certain favors when someone is tired or preoccupied (they’re less likely to put in the energy to disagree or refuse you). Don’t force opportunities, instead welcome them and keep your eyes open. If you’ve been waiting to throw a pitch at your boss, don’t force the conversation. This may require waiting for weeks before you get a good opportunity, but once you do, don’t blow it. When we encounter someone with, say, a proposal, half the battle can already be won or lost depending on their mood in the moment. Fact: Recently, a study of more than a thousand court decisions found that judges, who ought to be our rational-thinking exemplars, are just as susceptible to this notion as anyone. The study confirmed that prisoners are much more likely (up to 65 per cent more likely) to be paroled early in the day or shortly after a lunch break. Endless Possibilities The wonders of psychology are endless. It’s a field worth exploring, but is only useful by first putting in the effort to learn and implement. The above-mentioned ways to exploit psychology barely scratch the surface and require little more than mere awareness to employ. Each of the above factors are immensely useful in and of themselves. For instance, kinesics (the study of body language) can turn you into a walking lie detector if you care to be. If you don’t care to pick up on the impulses or tendencies of others, don’t care to expose situations to your benefit, don’t become aware of the body language that you exert and that others send your way, then you’re blinding yourself to a very interesting way to maximize on your exchanges throughout life.

There are an over-abundance of tactics people might use. So I suppose I should just use an extremely broad overview of “Tricks” as opposed to an extremely specific case-by-case type of basis. Using extreme emotion as a crutch, base, or a coverup.This one is probably one of the most common I’ve seen. People can disregard almost all accusations thrown their way just by breaking down into tears, laughter, passiveness, or distraction. But you can catch onto it if they “Use” it too often. Repetition and behaviour patterns are easily traceable, and not necessarily preventable, but occasionally interruptible. Opening a conversation with a threat, and following it up with a compromise.This one is used very rarely, from what I’ve seen and experienced. It’s usually used when someone is attempting to gain something. They open aggressively with either an open-ended threat, or an extremely specific threat. But immediately back out and offer a compromise of some kinda where both parties involved gain something. Even if the gain is little to nothing for the second party, the first party is beginning to look very “Generous” This is a tactic I’ve seen parents use occasionally, although on a much smaller scale. With less life-threatening involved. Ideally. Charm.Rule: 7+ Never. Trust. Charm. It’s not always used to *manipulate people into doing things for him/her. It’s not always used for “bad” things. Most of the time it’s used exclusively for innocent personal gain (I.E. popularity, more friends, easier access into certain low security buildings, depending on where you live; cheaper bartering deals.) So a rule of thumb: Until you’ve opened their personality book to at least pages three and four, don’t fall for their charm. *Munipulation isn’t always a vile, evil, horrible thing used by slimy snakes of sub-humane monsters. It’s similar to lying. (I.E. it has its place.) There’s a few common ones. I think all three have names that are commonly associated with the base principles. Such as “Gaslighting”, which is a name that’s so beyond vague… it irritates me when people use it. But as long as people are made known of, and are aware of the fact that these tactics exist? Call them whatever you want, if it assists you in the long and arduous process of remembering. Cheers! -Justin

There are probably dozens of different tactics and as such I have not studied this at length. But, I will try to share a few tactics I have learned and seen from my work experiences and academic life that I hope will help. Most manipulative strategies are designed to be covert so that the other person will not realize they are being manipulated until it is too late. A manager or co-worker, for example, may use the “wounded duck” syndrome to signal to a person that a task requires your personal skill and expertise, playing upon either your professionalism or upon your perception that you are the best at a certain task in a bid to off-load this onto you. Another popular strategy that is used by workers against their managers is something I have termed the “cower effect” which Maslow first talked about in one of his books. An employee who has a high power level imbalance with a manager will do just enough to not get in trouble. And, when the manager begins to apply that power imbalance to the relationship they will act “incompetent” while playing at the manager’s “perceived superiority in skills” and overall stronger motivation towards organizational goals (to put it bluntly, employees are not as motivated to accomplish organizational goals as managers who are more incentivized overall - this applies to top-down bureaucratic-style organizations) to “offload” tasks to them covertly. This is a common reason why many managers tend to work long hours while their employees leave after eight hours; a manager feels that “the place would fall apart without them” and as such take on more and more of the work to ensure their success (even though in many cases the employee can actually do the job better than they can).

I would like to know that you wouldn’t use ‘psychology’ to manipulate people before answering that — even if I had studied such devious behavior as how to manipulate individuals. However, something you are probably not in a position to do, as you probably haven’t got the ‘big money’ or the political power to do it: the use o large captive crowds and a corpus of sycophants who are prepared to do your bidding for either ‘political glory’ or ‘heavenly glory’. Examples: Billy Graham and his core team, and Hitler and his henchmen. What did they use to manipulate people and get them to follow without question? Answer in part: large public gatherings, oratory, and symbols/rituals.The symbols: Hitler’s swastika and nazi salute, and military goose stepping, and slogans (many of them anti-Jewish); Billy Graham’s bible raised in his hand, hymns, use of a favourite set of biblical verses to instill a sense of guilt and call on people to ‘repent and be saved’ so their immortal souls would not go to hell, the formal public act of ‘commitment to Jesus’ whereby people stepped out from the crowd and ‘went forward’ to be prayed over or repeat a prayer, have their contact details taken, to be counseled withe potential ‘follow up’ through a sympathetic church congregation. The singing and accompaniments and the tone of voice of the orator were enough to create a kind of ‘crowd hypnosis’ which would affect vulnerable people. Both were on-the-spot brainwashing. They would not have been so effective without mobs who were easy prey to indoctrination about the peril of ‘not believing’ — whether material or ‘spiritual’ death and destruction being the bogey.
