response.answer_text: Since I have experienced some form of psychological manipulation or abuse my whole life…I consider myself a self-proclaimed expert on the subject. Examples of tactics are: Lies, slander, and gossipTalking behind ones back but making it noticeable to the other person.Purposely saying or acting as if one does not believe you. No matter what it is you say.Trying to minimilaze your suffering by comparing it to an extreme anomaly. E.g. Your not going through anything. At least your not in another country on the other side of the world being physically tortured daily by different people!Triangulation…fake phone calls. Talking about you in front of you but using someone else's name.Purposely saying words they know make you uncomfortable or trigger your ptsd.Fishing “saying a rehearsed seemingly random slew of words in an effort to find your weaknesses or fears.Immediately changing their mood to cancel out yours for no reason. E.g. Your mad they get madder or extremely sad. Your sad they get real happy or mad.Changing their demeanor in public or around others…e.g. joining in on bullying once they see mutual associates.Always pretending to not have money or anything you might want or need because they know you are struggling. They might also have a surplus of everything and it is obvious. This is often coupled with blatant lies like “I can't give you the $20 I owe you since I have to pay my $3500 per month rent bill on my third apartment…They will go out of their way to find friends of theirs who are sensitive about experiences you have had and use their possibly worse experiences as a comparison tool. Kind of like a “this person went through much worse….how can you be so insensitive?”Mimicking and mirroring you…stealing your jokes, your references, your persona, your ideas and beliefs..and claiming them as their own. Even going so far as to claiming you stole ideas from them.Pretending like your wallet or phone is suddenly missing and you must be the culprit. Trying to get you to question yourself.Constantly putting your character to the test when it is not necessary. Then tricking you into looking guilty by saying out loud to everyone how you must be guilty because you are defending yourself.Only being nice to you when it is clear that you have reached a breaking point.Manipulating your emotions knowing full and well how traumatic it is to you.Purposely playing music or YouTube videos that aim at triggering your ptsd or attacking your insecurities. Then giving you a facial expression that lets you and them know that they are doing it intentionally and sometimes sadistically.Expecting special treatment for trivial things like allowing you to use their lighter, or asking for a cigarette.They will never let anyone know how much you actually help them…but will let everyone else know how much they helped you that day…they will purposely forget that you provided a lot more emotionally, financially, mentally, and everything in between…than they ever did.Purposely withholding information from you…pretending that they and others know something about you that you dont.Continuing to tell lies and rumours about you even though they have already been Proven false.Video taping and recording you without your knowledge. Taking things out of context when sharing illegal footage with others.Blackmailing you to do what they want or give them special treatment.Gas lighting. Crazy making behaviour.Letting you know new methods for attempting suicide or claiming that if you wanted to kill yourself…you would have by now. That you haven't tried hard enough and that you obviously must not want to do it. E.g. “just jump off a building…you have no excuse. “ (this is messed up but is used on me quite frequently)There are many many more. But the rest might be too triggering or unbelievable.

1. Whenever someone is angry and confrontational, stand next to them instead of in front of them. You won’t appear as so much of a threat, and they eventually calm down. 2. Open with “I need your help.” People don’t like the guilt of not helping someone out. When asking for a favour from someone, begin your request by saying “I need your help.” It greatly increases your chances of getting that favour done.  3. Rephrase what the other person says and repeat it back to them. This makes them think you’re listening and really interested in what they’re saying. It makes them feel validated. Obviously, you don’t want to overdo this. 4. If you want someone to agree with you, nod while you talk.This gets the other person to nod too, and they begin to subconsciously think they agree with you. 5. If someone doesn't like you, ask to borrow a pencil. It is a small enough favour that they won’t say no, and it gets them to like you more. 6. Fold your arms to determine interest. If someone is observing you, they will likely mimic you. Fold your arms, and see if they do it, too. 7. Repeat a person’s name many times during a conversation. It helps you remember it, and makes them like you more.

Nod your head If you want people to agree with you, then all you have to do is nod. In a 1980 study published in the Basic and Applied Psychology journal, scientists found that when people nod while listening to something, they are more likely to agree with it. So if you nod while speaking, the other person may begin to nod as well and start to agree with you, without even knowing it. Nodding your head when asking someone a question will also make them more likely to agree with you or comply with your request. Mimic people’s body language Mimicry, or mirroring, is when you essentially copy someone’s body language or speech patterns. There is plenty of research that suggests that if you copy someone’s body language, they are more likely to identify with you subconsciously, which makes them more likely to do what you want. Marco Iacoboni, author of Mirroring People: The Science of Empathy and How We Connect with Others, claims that mirroring can help establish rapport, which is an important step to becoming friends or acquaintances with another person. He explains that exhibiting similar actions, attitudes, and speech patterns as another person may lead them to believe that you are more similar to them and thus more likely to be a friend. Ask people for favors when they’re tired When someone is tired, they are more likely to agree because they are so worn down. This is because both their physical and mental energy levels are depleted. This kind of manipulation can be found in car dealerships, where car dealers try to wear you down into buying a car. Furthermore, based on a study published in the Journal of Marketing Research, CBS News reports that advertisers are more likely to “win over” consumers when those consumers are tired.

Manipulation itself has a negative undertone. When you create an intention to manipulate people, you create an energy that has motive of gaining something from others by misleading or controlling them. Manipulative intentions creates an energy within your brain. The neural network builds a negative charges simulating brain area connecting with reward through smartness. During this process emotional side connected with empathy is not activated hence you are not able to build any emotional connection with people. So any manipulative technique can only be done if you are meeting or dealing with same set of people only once. If you are meeting same set of people again in social setting then second time you would not be able to take advantage of their ignorance or innocence. Also people with higher intuitive skill are able to read such intentions far easier than those who are not intuitive. Hence there is no long term benefit in manipulating others. On other hand if you learn skills based on Trust and Empathy you will able to build far stronger association with people and thus accomplish much larger things in life. I would recommend you to go through this article on 10 Effective Ways to Become a Successful Leader by #Beyondmind .

You don't. If you want to win friends and influence people (who doesn't?), then your only possible approach is honesty. If you are the sort of person that people have reason to like and trust, then they will. But if you are trying to manipulate them into liking and trusting you, then you'll fail: people are rarely as stupid as manipulators believe them to be, and they'll see through you easily. So just take a genuine interest in the people around you: ask them about their lives and interests, really listen to the answers, and respond by telling them about yourself (briefly) and by following up on what they've told you with more conversation. Make sure your dealings with them are in their best interests as well as yours. Reading people is just a matter of paying attention to them. Real attention, not distracted by wondering how you can make them do what you want, or wondering what they think of you, just thinking about them and their reactions and needs. In case the question changes, the one I answered was: "How do I manipulate people? Reading  whole Sherlock Holmes series really got me into it. And it continued  with the tv series and the movies. After I completed them I found  Elementary and Mr. Robot and completed them as well. So now I want to  know how to do such things like reading someone I mean I'm not trying to  be a Sherlock Holmes. I just want it to use it in my real life  especially for my future job. I believe this helps you to get more  friends and make someone love you but as I said I'm planning to learn  this to only be successful at my job and life because I believe it does."

A businessman who keeps earning by fooling people, a politician who has built a career on conning people, a self proclaimed saint who has ashrams where he keeps a mass who can kill for their guruji. It can be anyone who is a master manipulator.You know it's an outright lie. Yet they are telling you this lie with a straight face.Once your gaslighter tells you lies and you have proof about it. They'd deny everything.Now, you question your memory or intentions. Did I hear it all wrong? Was I disrespectful to this person when I confronted him/her about a lie?When tgis person keep commenting on you negatively, this person also Praises you once in a while. You think, "Well maybe they aren't so bad."They'll align people against you. Mostly your near and dear ones are used as a human shield. They'll use these people to keep you off kilter. If you question the gaslighter or catch them red handed, they'll confuse you or put you in guilt by using these people.They keep you confuse and indecisive and tell other people that you are crazy. Yes, these gaslighters are very dangerous. They can go any measures to make you look like the bad guy.

To be clear, influence techniques work at least partly in the target’s interest. Manipulation techniques—which are mostly the same—work solely in the manipulator’s interest. Manipulators address or threaten three fundamental, evolution-driven needs that I call The 3Cs of Why: our need to feel in control of our lives (resources, freedom etc.). Manipulators often suggest you’re about to lose something.our need to feel connected to other people (recognition, belonging, etc.). Manipulators often suggest you’re about to be isolated or excluded.our need for consistency (expectations vs reality, causes vs effects, previous vs current, values vs behaviours etc). Manipulators often tell you things consistent with the self-image you want.Sometimes the border between influence and manipulation is hard to draw. For example, the button in elevators that allows you to close the doors sooner often doesn’t work. It’s there to answer your need to feel in control. Interested? Check out my book, « Your influencing instincts », available on Amazon.

6 Smart Psychological Tricks Starbucks Uses In Their Marketing To Make You Buy More When you hear the words ‘Let’s Grab a Coffee’, what comes to mind? The answer to all of us will be just one: Starbucks! A drive down to Starbucks so that you can choose from a wide menu which has millions of components, makes the soul dance. The aroma, the ease of takeaways, and your personalized coffee cup, you feel valued. However, you are often forced to wonder, how does the world-known Brand keep its brand image and customer traction high, even when it has often been called an expensive place to find your daily dose of coffee at! The secret recipe to Starbucks success lies in its crazy yet effective psychological tricks, that it incorporates at worldwide stores to keep a steady flow of revenues! 1) Not-so comfy furniture  Aside from the layout of Starbucks, where most tables are crammed together and there is hardly any corridor space, Starbucks surprisingly puts extra efforts to have sturdy and backless chairs. There is a reason why no customer can manage to sit on those chairs for more than 30mins. So even if you might have wanted to chat with your friend over coffee, you’ll prefer to make it a takeaway and go for a walk, leaving space for a new customer. 2) The exclusive aura  Every time you step into Starbucks or check their social media handles, they always have a limited-edition drink making the rounds. These drinks are not just unique to the Brand but are also exclusive because of short tenure on the menu. This way, a rush of orders come in because nobody, nobody in this generation wants to miss out on what’s trending! 3) Interio Lighting  Starbucks follows a very simple yet straightforward way to light its area, with the dining area having a dark misty vibe whereas the order counter and the product shelves are always well-lit. The idea is to attract your mind to the light as soon as you enter the store so that you know where to spend your money at! 4) Unique Roasting  For the beginners, you must know that a strong roasting process makes your coffee extremely bitter. So even if you usually prefer black coffee, a Starbucks black brew isn’t something you can easily get accustomed to. Which is why, most people prefer to buy Lattes or Frappuccino’s at the store outlet, even if the espresso is cheaper. So, you buy an expensive drink because the brand knows your taste buds well! 5) The luxury vibe  Starbucks has made a name in the elite club, not just because of its store design but also because of the customer service it gives. Very rare coffee shops have windows for customers to feel a personal connection with baristas directly interacting with them. Along with that, the premium way of using high-quality coffee glasses, top-class décor and presentation, it urges you to spend more, so that you get to be a part of something luxurious and unique! 6) Power of branding  Along with everything else, Starbucks knows where to spend its earnings. From astounding amounts of money used in marketing, it has kept its commercials as fan favourites, over the past few years. From its reward system to its customized products, it wants the customer to feel at home, to trust the brand. Starbucks even takes care of minute details like placing the cash register right so that the customer can absorb the store feel first and keeping menu prices not rounded up to not attract attention to change, all done to make the most out of its business model. When it’s a win, it is a win. Source - Google Happy reading… Thankyou!!!

Manipulate people in what way? Just by existing you are affecting others, your own presence affects others . Or do you mean manipulate for your own personal gain? The simple fact that you are asking a question in such broad terminology easily tells me that you have room to grow and mature in understanding human natures (yes, plural). Before you even try and manipulate others, you should learn about yourself first, what affects you, in what way do certain thoughts and actions affect you, and quite importantly, the different ways you would respond, and what would be the best way to respond to each situation. Once you know that, you will have half your answer. The other half is acknowledging that as we are all different, we also have many similarities, and being able to see and understand these differences and similarities can you change yourself to bring about a better outcome. Please note, if after analyzing yourself you are still only thinking about personal gain, know that you are digging a very deep hole when others feel betrayed, to the point that there will be no remedy or way to “fix” things. The words of a wise man are “someone who only thinks about themselves, never get very far in life”. If you still don't understand what I'm saying, just stay away from manipulation and be yourself and understand yourself while being compassionate towards others. Since other people may not have had a similar life, but might be living a very difficult life.

This one's a funny one. Have you seen this one friend texting you out of nowhere? Months apart, no messages, no calls, unanswered texts, and then suddenly a Hi drops in to your inbox. Then, it is followed with, “How have you been?”, or “Following your recent successes. Good job, man.” So, you hesitate just a little, then you say, “Hey, man. Haha, yeah. Thank you.” Then, you wait. You wait. He springs online. Sees your message. You can tell what's coming next but you wait to see if it's not what you think. He starts to type. Then, deletes. It shows online. He starts to type again. Makes up his mind. Deletes again. Then, finally, one final push. Send. Message pops up, “Awesome! Listen, I need your help.” There it is. He doesn't remember you because he has been following on your accomplishments, recently. He probably doesn't even care. He needs a favour from you but he feels shame because he never responded to your texts or calls. So, he tries to make it about you by dropping in a compliment — something nice to soften the blow before he asks you for what he needs. It's cute how they think people can't smell their bullshit a mile away. Please spare both of us the trouble and get straight to the point. Oh and by the way — we know.

I once read this story on Tumblr about how a girl got a guy she was into to fall in love with her. Basically, every time she saw him, she’d strike up a conversation and offer him one of his favourite candy. I forgot what it was, so for the sake of this answer, it’s Airheads. She sees the guy. “Hey guy! How has your day been? What class are you going to next? Here, have an airhead!” Then they’d talk for a while, and Guy would walk off, thinking Wow, these Airheads are good. Damn, I’ve gotta thank Tumblr Girl for that. I wonder how she always has them on her. Hey, Tumblr Girl. My brain is now gonna dwell on her for a while since I’ve associated her with my favourite candy. Before you know it, Guy starts associating her with his favourite candy, and as such she’s always associated with good things in his head. "You hurt me." "I'm sorry. Ugh, I hate myself. I'm such an idiot. I can't believe I did that. What is wrong with me? I'm so stupid and horrible." Apologies. With master manipulators, they sound genuine but are really the opposite. These people don't just say sorry: they complain about how they're so stupid, so horrible, how they despise themselves for what they did. It makes you automatically start saying "Oh, no, you're not. You're really nice and smart!" and you don't realise until ir's too late that they've tricked you. I have a friend like this. Gina* is also the type of girl to say "I'm depressed" for every minor inconvenience. She always brings Lucozade into school: when I first met her and she said this to me, I gasped and said, "Why?" Guess what she said? "I forgot to bring my Lucozade into school today." So, yeah, she's nice in most other aspects (except for her irritating overusage of the phrase "Do you think I care?") but these are her flaws. Everybody has them. And … frankly, she's manipulative. She plays on people's heartstrings. You go from boiling mad to sad and sympathetic in a matter of seconds. Don't be like Gina. Own up to your mistakes, and don't manipulate people into feeling sorry for you instead of just genuinely apologising. *Names changed.

People often respond to subtle body language queues. If you're a salesperson and are trying to convince someone to buy something, you ask them to buy and nod  your head yes. People respond in kind. You start by asking them questions you know they'll answer yes to. You get them in the 'yes' frame of mind. Once this happens your chances of making the sale increase. Another technique I learned in sales is to let the other person talk more, even if that means having an uncomfortable silence at some point. People want to talk about themselves. When they do, they often give out very private information. The more information you have, the better your chances of influencing them. To me, this is not really manipulation. It can be used for good or bad. For example, if I'm selling life insurance to an elderly person and they can barely afford their medicines every month, I find it distasteful to use these techniques to make the sale. But, if I know the person has the money and the need, I'm going to try and help them by using these techniques. Sometimes people really don't know what's best for them. If you're knowledgeable in a particular field and find someone who can benefit from what you have to offer, it's okay to use these techniques in my opinion.

You always think that others are controlling you, or that you can be manipulated by others. But in many cases, you manipulate yourself. The psychologist Jung once said this conclusion: Your subconscious mind is controlling your life, but you call it destiny. Your subconscious mind is manipulating you, and you have been led by it. A project or an exam was prepared enough, but when I came on the field, I couldn't help but worry. I couldn't help but flashed out the situation after the failure in my mind, and finally didn't exert his due strength. Wanting to work hard and succeed in your consciousness, not wanting to endure failure, wanting to give up is your subconscious mind.When you are dating, you have planned how to confess in advance. But when you face the person you like, you can't tell. You want to confess consciousness. And you feel that you don't deserve to have good love, and fear of rejection is subconscious.In the workplace, you dare not show yourself or fight for opportunities for yourself. If you do so, you have no sense of presence in the company. You are often neglected and miss many opportunities for promotion. These behaviors show that your subconscious mind is: you are afraid of being different from others and afraid of making mistakes in your work....However, the influence of the subconscious is far more than the above. In addition to affecting our decisions and actions regarding the current situation, and letting us miss opportunities in hesitation, the subconscious also affects our future and denisty

Remember your last trip to the restaurant. Olson claims that you are twice as likely to choose a dish from the top or bottom of the menu, since these are the parts of the list that first draw attention to themselves.  "But if someone asks you why you ordered salmon, you will surely answer that you really wanted to try it," says the researcher. In other words, we come up with the reasons for our choice, despite the fact that he was planned by the restaurant administration. What about the choice of wine in the supermarket? Jennifer Mackendrick and her colleagues at the University of Leicester found that French or German music that plays in the store influences the choice of wine from these regions by consumers - of course, purely unconscious. It is less clear how this data correlates with other forms of manipulating thoughts that are the subject of lengthy debate. During the presidential election in the United States in 2000, supporters of the democrat Al Gore claimed that the video shown by the Republicans was 25 frames with the words “rats”. The supporters of Gore were convinced that this subconscious message harmed the candidate. An experiment conducted in the laboratory under similar conditions, confirmed that 25 frames with the inscription really negatively affect the rating of the policy. Whether such a strategy can have a long-term effect remains doubtful. But it is likely that other types of manipulation affect our behavior without our awareness of this. One impressive experiment showed that the demonstration of a photo of a winning athlete markedly increased the efficiency of telephone sales, despite the fact that most respondents did not even remember the image. There is evidence that if someone gives you hot tea, you will perceive this person as more emotional. A bad smell can make people judge more strictly.

Stonewalling - a person who uses this resorts to passive-aggressive behavior and instead of communicating the problem, they rather stay quiet. This is not the silence that accompanies peace, it's the contrary. The other person stays quiet while making you feel their indifference and anger. By doing this, the other person tends to get anxious, deeply upset, or overthink about the situation which then would make them find ways to appease the person who's stonewalling them.Gaslighting - When someone gaslights you, they are trying to confuse your sense of reality. For instance, you remember your significant other said “I went out with a friend last night “ but when you reminded him of this conversation, he said “I never said that. Are you sure of what you heard?” By this you start to doubt your own senses and perception. Someone who constantly does this aims to weaken your sense of self which makes you an easy victim to emotional abuse and manipulation. Gaslighting also involves invalidation of emotions and opinions. Someone might tell you “That's not a big deal.” over something they did which is upsetting to you. This makes you question your own principles whether you're overreacting or not.

response.answer_text: Have you ever had a friend that constantly spins lies, betrays you and then somehow manages to still be in your life? We've all been there. That friend who plays the victim card and tugs at your heartstrings. The conversation often goes like this: You: “So why did you lie?” Manipulator: “I'm not in a good place right now. I'm depressed and nobody is there for me, including you.” The use of the word “you” makes it personal. Now that he's added you into the story, you will instantly become overwhelmed by negative emotions, and negative emotions lead to irrational choices. Here is an interesting experiment you can try on friends or foes. It is simple and nobody gets hurt. It relies on the operant conditioning procedure where a reward is given for a specific response. When engaged in a conversation (it should be more the 15 minutes, perhaps about a psychological topic) pay attention to the eye blinks of your ‘subject’. If you want to be very scientific about it try to gauge the base rate. Then every time a blink occurs make a friendly smile and/or slightly nod your head. (This should ideally occur half a second after the blink). Over time you should observe a noticeable increase in the blinking rate. Once established, you can move on to intermittent reinforcement, decrease the ‘reward’ to being given only after two blinks. For more sophisticated schedules of reinforcement look them up Reinforcement - Wikipedia Fun variation: every time they use a personal pronoun smile and nod. You'll be surprised how much the use of them will increase. For full disclosure you should reveal to them what happened afterwards.

response.answer_text: Here’s a good one, and you’ll never realize it’s a manipulative tactic. When someone has a complaint or an issue with you—such as a higher-up, sometimes they’ll throw in something like “everyone has mentioned it”, or “everyone feels that way about you.” Of course, they won’t tell you exactly WHO else feels this way, or exactly who has brought it up. Most research on manipulation is primarily done, understandably, in the context of marketing. If we consider manipulation as techniques used to get other people to do what you want, this is basically the definition of a good advertisement. I will provide a couple of terms, but I encourage you to study advertisements; dissect the video and analyse the components; how are they trying to sell the product, in what way is the portrait of the product framed? What demographic is the ad targeting? Is the product the focus of the ad, or are they trying to associate the product with a specific feeling or lifestyle? Foot in the door - Basically, you ask for something small in order to later get something big. A salesman comes to your house and says “Hey, are you interested in this vacuum cleaner? It only costs 5 bucks” You think well yeah, that is kind of cheap, and ten minutes later you find out that the 5 bucks is part of a payment plan spanning 24 months. You feel a bit cheated but also you experience cognitive dissonance because you have invested so much of your time listening to this otherwise nice man and you initially thought it was going to be a real bargain. You two may even have had chance to develop and inside joke and well, maybe you are a little bit attached because you have had a rough day and finally someone made you laugh. You figure screw it, maybe I can at least make this guy’s evening a little better and agree to buy the vacuum cleaner. The salesman of course did act according to a company wide script the entire time, making this somewhat overly agreeable hypothetical person almost feel guilty for not buying the vacuum cleaner sooner and stop wasting the salesman’s time. Door in the face - Ask for something big, then ask for what you originally want. Ever tried to make your parents do something you simply knew they were not going to do? The key to success is to induce a negative feeling and then a feeling of relief when the pressure of that request vanishes. “Mom, I have met a girl I really like on the internet. She lives on the other side of the country, is 20 years older than me but I think we love each other. I need to meet her, can you take me?” If your mother believes you, she is probably going to be very concerned. Feed her a few minutes of agony, then tell her the truth “Actually, I just need a ride to my friend, he lives downtown.” Manipulation in its essence is something you sell, and your variables are the product, the customer and the pitch. One of these variables are dependent upon the other two, triangular harmony.

“I can tell you’re lying because…….” Typically that’s followed by reference to some body language cue the person being spoken to made. It’s a ludicrously overplayed psychological pressuring gambit used by people who give themselves far too much credit in their ability to detect lies. Rather than indicate lies, it’s a tactic that can often take you further from the truth. If you use it to pressure someone that you assume is lying, you’ll more than likely succeed in nothing more than eliciting further body language from them that you believe represents dishonesty and getting them to lie simply to get you off their back. They may have been telling you the truth all along. Body language is such a diverse thing from person to person and culture to culture that it could never be a reliable indicator of someone’s honesty. A much more reliable method of determining truth is to get the person to tell their story a few times. A lot of inconsistencies are better indicator of deceit than any body language cue, as are new details being added to the story with each telling. If their story stays pretty much the same each time they tell it, they’ve likely given you the truth.

Well, in product designing, a lot of psychological tricks are used so that the user of the product uses the product in desired way. This can be regarded as manipulation of behavior but it causes no harm to person in general and society in particular. One such example of using psychological trick to manipulate someone in context of problem solving and product designing can be understood from the following case study: It was observed that when people enter an elevator, they press the buttons of the elevator multiple times. 8 out of 10 people have tendency of repeatedly pressing the close button till the door finally closes. 7 out 10 people have tendency of pressing the floor button more than once. Now, the thing to be understood here is that pressing the same button again and again will not change the outcome and will also not certainly fasten the process. It will only cause more wear and tear and this results in frequent damaging of buttons. What would you do to solve this problem? . . . There could be many possible solutions to this problem . However, the solution that R&D of elevator companies came up with is simple, effective and out of the box. In order to prevent what was happening, one of the solution could be to offer a distraction. What could be a better source of distraction than a mirror! So these elevator companies installed mirrors in the elevators. This solution has actually successfully solved the problem. It has been found that in elevators without the mirrors, the buttons get damaged twice as fast as in elevators with the mirrors. The above case study was an excellent example of how human behavior can be manipulated using psychology. Product designing involves lot of such manipulations

Gaslighting is one way. Gaslighting is a form of manipulation that seeks to sow seeds of doubt in a targeted individual or in members of a targeted group, hoping to make them question their own memory, perception, and sanity. Using persistent denial, misdirection, contradiction, and lying, it attempts to destabilize the target and delegitimize the target's belief. Instances may range from the denial by an abuser that previous abusive incidents ever occurred up to the staging of bizarre events by the abuser with the intention of disorienting the victim. The term owes its origin to the 1938 Patrick Hamilton play Gas Lightand its 1940 and 1944 film adaptations. The term has been used in clinical and research literature, as well as in political commentary. Sourced from wikipedia

Psycological manipulation is a type of social influence that aims to change the behavior or perception of others through indirect, deceptive, or underhanded tactics. By advancing the interests of the manipulator, often at another's expense, such methods could be considered exploitative and devious. Social influence is not necessarily negative. For example, people such as friends, family and doctors, can try to persuade to change clearly unhelpful habits and behaviors. Social influence is generally perceived to be harmless when it respects the right of the influenced to accept or reject it, and is not unduly coercive. Depending on the context and motivations, social influence may constitute underhanded manipulation.
